awd_titl_txt: You Teach Physical Science: Noyce Scholars Enhancing Technical Capacity in Arkansas
awd_abstract_narration:
The YouTeach Noyce scholarship program is supporting 28 undergraduate chemistry and physics  majors to become highly qualified 7-12th grade physical science teachers. The program is partnering with and enhancing YouTeach, the University of Arkansas' UTeach replication site. This project is aiding the growth of YouTeach by increasing the number of participants through scholarship support and by allowing more advanced undergraduates to join the program with the support of a Master Teacher (MT). The MT is also providing induction support to the early graduates. All Noyce scholars are receiving additional training and support in the teaching demands of the high-need classroom from the MT beyond that called for by the UTeach model. Special attention is being paid to the recruiting and support of a diverse teacher community. 

The Noyce scholars are benefiting from the extensive connections with local school districts and teachers that have grown out of previous funded projects including Fayetteville Public Schools, Fort Smith Public Schools, Siloam Springs School District, and Springdale Public Schools. The leadership team is well placed in national professional organizations to make lessons learned through this project available at the national level. This project is developing a lasting model of the cooperation of physics and chemistry departments to produce science teachers, most of whom will teach both chemistry and physics as the new licensure in Arkansas requires expertise in teaching both disciplines.

Placement of 28 qualified physical science teachers in Arkansas classrooms is improving STEM education and encouraging matriculation into STEM majors by students in high-needs classrooms across a state with very poor college attendance rates. Integration into Professional Learning Communities developed as part of the College Ready MSP is providing professional support and informing teachers of the barriers to college attendance. All recruiting activities are being carefully documented to form a resource that will be published and featured in the PTEC library, a component of comPADRE and PhysTEC.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This NSF supported project: You Teach Physical Science: Noyce Scholars Enhancing Technical Capacity in Arkansas had two primary goals: 1) hasten and enhance growth of the UAteach Program at the University of Arkansas (UA), and 2) recruit and provide Noyce Scholarship support for the education of 25 chemistry and physics majors as they pursued teaching careers in 7-12 grade physical science in high-need schools, thus enhancing STEM education in one of the nation's poorest regions. Funding started in 2012 when the UA was developing a Uteach replication site, soon called the UAteach program, through collaboration between its Colleges of Education and Arts & Sciences. A Master Teacher (MT) experienced in high school chemistry/physics teaching was hired with grant support to work with two other MTs experienced in teaching high school biology and math. Together, they indeed enhanced development of the UAteach program through recruiting students into the UAteach minor, teaching UAteach courses, assisting STEM majors in the program as they planned and conducted classroom interactions with area junior/senior high schools, and training them for the demands of high-need schools, particularly relevant to the region. The chemistry/physics MT supported by the grant focused on recruiting chemistry and physics majors and supporting them in the program. Thus, the first primary goal of the grant of enhancing the roll out and development of the UAteach program was successfully achieved.

Prior to funding, the physics department regularly produced physics teachers each year through its Physics Teacher Education Coalition (PhysTEC) site. Indeed, the UA was one of the primary program institutions at the onset of the PhysTEC program, and by 2011 our physics department had been in the PhysTEC 5+ Club more than once, a distinction indicating graduation of five or more certified physics teachers in a single year. In contrast, the UA chemistry department struggled to produce any teachers, despite graduating nearly three times as many majors per year as the physics department.

Intellectual Merit: In the spirit of the Uteach program, our UAteach program trained future STEM teachers by forming collaborations between the College of Education, with expertise in training and certifying future teachers, and the College of Arts and Sciences in which the STEM degree programs reside. This grant also teamed faculty and advisors from both the chemistry and physics departments in the hopes of leveraging experience within the physics department in mentoring and producing physics teachers to improve the production of chemistry graduates pursuing careers in 7-12 grade physical science and chemistry teaching.

Both the chemistry/physics Master Teacher and the PI taught UAteach courses, mentored chemistry and physics majors with UAteach minors toward eligibility for Noyce Scholarship support, and upon graduation supported former Noyce Scholars in their professional development after they started teaching careers. Eligibility for Noyce Scholarship support in this program required junior/senior status, a GPA of at least 3.0, and a commitment to teach for one year in a high-need school for each semester of support on a Noyce Scholarship. Noyce Scholars were also limited to a maximum of four semesters of support. Recruiting chemistry and physics majors toward teaching careers in high-need school districts proved to be considerably harder than envisioned at the time the proposal was written. Many strategies were tried over the years of the grant, but none produced significant increases in the numbers of chemistry and physics majors in the UAteach program. Of those that were recruited, another challenge was to get them to commit to the requirements of Noyce support. Thus, we were not able to achieve the goal of recruiting and supporting 25 Noyce Scholars into careers as teachers in high-need schools. Nevertheless, we have had success in producing a diverse group of 10 physics and five chemistry graduates supported as Noyce Scholars. Many of these Noyce graduates received professional development opportunities with grant support by, e.g., attending and contributing to regional or national Noyce conferences. 

Broader Impact: Of the 15 Noyce Scholars supported over the life of this grant, two have yet to start teaching careers, nine have now taught in a high-need school for a number of years more than sufficient to meet their Noyce commitment, and four more are teaching in high-need schools but have yet to complete their Noyce commitment. Producing highly qualified junior high school physical science and high school chemistry and physics teachers, i.e., teachers with degrees in the subjects they teach, as well as placing them in high-need schools was accomplished though this grant. This will result in better educational experiences for students in each school into which our Noyce Scholars are placed, which in turn will motivate more young people to be attracted into STEM careers.﻿ Having such an impact in high-need schools is likely to reach students not typically attracted to STEM careers.

 


Last Modified: 01/30/2024
Modified by: William F Oliver
